title: Abstract of judgment: Does debtor need to be served with copy before recording with county registrar?
question: I won a large judgment in a small claims case recently received an abstract of judgment from the court. I thought that the next step was to file the abstract with the LA County Recorder's office. When looking for instructions to do this on the LA County Recorder's Web site, it lists two fee schedules for recording abstracts of judgment:
answers: If you pay an extra fee to the county recorder, he will serve the notice of involuntary lien.
answer_card_text:
Answer
Susan Kathryn Ashabraner
Estate Planning Attorney in Fullerton, CA

If you pay an extra fee to the county recorder, he will serve the notice of involuntary lien.
